required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Cervical Stabilization Exercise in Violinists With Chronic Neck Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Cervical Stabilization Exercises Improved Pain, Disability, and Physical Impairments in University Violinists With Nonspecific Neck Pain

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine the influence of a 6-week cervical stabilization exercise program in university violin players with chronic nonspecific neck pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in self-reported neck pain: Numeric Rating Scale
primary_outcome.description: Measured by the Numeric Rating Scale (min 0-max 10, better outcome 0 worst outcome 10)
Measured by the Neck Disability Index (10-item questionnaire, each item scored from 0 to 5, result expressed as percentage, better outcome 0 worst outcome 100%)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in deep neck flexors function
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by the craniocervical flexion test with a pressure biofeedback unit (higher pressure represents better outcome)
Measured using a stopwatch for the successful time holding the head in cervical flexion and extension positions (longer time represent better outcome)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in cervical joint position sense
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by the cervcal joint reposition error with a laser pointer (short distance represent better outcome)

intervention.description: The participants followed instructional videos and performed the cervical stabilization exercise program at home for 20 minutes/day, 3 days/week, for 6 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- duration of playing the instrument longer than 5 years
- practicing the violin more than 5 hours/week
- constant neck pain for more than 3 months or at least 2 pain episodes in the last 3 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous surgery in the neck and shoulder regions
- current participation in a structured exercises program
- current treatment for neck and shoulder pain
- red flags suggesting of cancer, infection, vascular insufficiency, and etc. during history taking
- neurological symptoms of the upper extremities during screening tests (e.g. Spurling test and upper limb tension tests)

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
